title: 10 Best Humidifiers That Give Our Editors Allergy Relief (2025)
description: Combatting sore throats and runny noses, one liter at a time
author: Terri Williams, Julia Harrison
byline: Terri Williams, Julia Harrison, Lizzie Soufleris
excerpt: Say sayonara to sore throats and dry noses with some of the best humidifiers from Dyson, Levoit, Blueair, and more that are editor-tested for allergy relief

The right relative humidity can decrease allergy symptoms by adding moisture to the air, which soothes dry nasal passages and sore throats, as well as reduces inflammation, making it easier to breathe and alleviate congestion.Below, our staffers and contributors provide a rundown of some of their favorite models they’ve tested over the last couple years in city apartments with clanky radiators, during particularly brutal spring allergy seasons and beyond. We walk you through the many types of humidifiers we’ve tested, their bells and whistles, along with how to choose the right model depending on your room size. We even interview Ratika Gupta, MD, a board-certified allergist at ENT and Allergy Associates in Brooklyn, to answer your FAQs. Since it fills from the top, the highly portable humidifier is both leak-proof and easy to fill and clean, and it’s compatible with essential oils (note: Dr. Gupta suggests avoiding diffusing scents via your humidifier). Even though it’s economically priced, the Levoit Dual 200S has a built-in humidistat that can automatically detect if the room is too dry or too humid and adjust the mist levels accordingly. Can is the operative word, since not all of these accessories are created equal. If you see white dust while using the cartridges or filters, it could indicate that they’re not really working.Typical projected coverage: When shopping for portable or compact humidifiers, you can expect that they efficiently cover up to 400 square feet—that’s the average size of most bedrooms. Humidifiers suited for medium-size rooms, like a living or dining room, often cover from 400 square feet to 1,000 square feet. Most of the picks on our list tap out at about 1,000 square feet, meaning they can humidify a decent amount of the home, if not an entire floor.FAQsHow do I clean my humidifier? According to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), you should be cleaning your humidifier every third day that you use it. While that may seem overly conscientious for people who work five days a week, we recommend cleaning your humidifier weekly if you’re able to. Keep a close eye on any interior filters for mold or residue, especially in the first weeks of introducing the humidifier into your space.To clean the humidifier, unplug it, empty the tank, wipe all surfaces dry, and refill before reconnecting it to power. For portable humidifiers, it’s important to clean these daily to reduce the growth of any microorganisms or mildew. You don’t want to accidentally humidify your space with mold particles, after all.

However, if you put it on high, you’ll use up to eight ounces of moisture per hour, which means the unit could be out of water in less than eight hours.

Distilled versus tap water: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), using distilled water reduces the formation of white dust around the humidifier and also prevents the growth of scale caused by the minerals in tap water.

Cartridges and filters: If the humidifier includes demineralization cartridges or filters, using them can also remove minerals (in fact, you may not need to use distilled water, but check the owner’s manual to be sure). Can is the operative word, since not all of these accessories are created equal. If you see white dust while using the cartridges or filters, it could indicate that they’re not really working.

Typical projected coverage: When shopping for portable or compact humidifiers, you can expect that they efficiently cover up to 400 square feet—that’s the average size of most bedrooms. Humidifiers suited for medium-size rooms, like a living or dining room, often cover from 400 square feet to 1,000 square feet. Most of the picks on our list tap out at about 1,000 square feet, meaning they can humidify a decent amount of the home, if not an entire floor.

FAQs

How do I clean my humidifier? According to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), you should be cleaning your humidifier every third day that you use it. While that may seem overly conscientious for people who work five days a week, we recommend cleaning your humidifier weekly if you’re able to. Keep a close eye on any interior filters for mold or residue, especially in the first weeks of introducing the humidifier into your space.

To clean the humidifier, unplug it, empty the tank, wipe all surfaces dry, and refill before reconnecting it to power. For portable humidifiers, it’s important to clean these daily to reduce the growth of any microorganisms or mildew. You don’t want to accidentally humidify your space with mold particles, after all.
